1.1: The Lord spoke to Moses in the Sinai desert, in the meeting tent on the first day of the second month, in the second year after they had come out of the land of Egypt. The Lord said,
1.2: “Number all the people of Israel, by their families, by those of their fathers’ houses. Write down the names of every male, head by head,
1.3: twenty years old and older. You and Aaron number by their armies whoever in Israel is able to go out to war.
1.4: A man from each family should be with you to help you. Each one should be the head of his father’s house.
1.5: These are the names of the men who will help you: Shedeur’s son Elizur from Reuben,
1.9: and Helon’s son Eliab from Zebulun.
1.10: From the sons of Joseph there will be Ammihud’s son Elishama from Ephraim, and Pedahzur’s son Gamaliel from Manasseh.
1.11: There will be Gideoni’s son Abidan from Benjamin,
1.15: and Enan’s son Ahira from Naphtali.”
1.16: These were the ones chosen from the people. They were the leaders of their fathers’ families, the heads of thousands in Israel.
1.17: Moses and Aaron took these men who had been chosen by name.
1.18: And they gathered all the people together on the first day of the second month. The people gave their names by families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names from twenty years old and older, head by head.
1.19: They did just as the Lord had told Moses. So he numbered them in the desert of Sinai.
1.20: The sons of Reuben, Israel’s first-born, were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
1.21: The number of the family of Reuben was 46,500.
1.22: The sons of Simeon were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
1.23: The number of the family of Simeon was 59,300.
1.24: The sons of Gad were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
1.25: The number of the family of Gad was 45,650.
1.26: The sons of Judah were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
1.27: The number of the family of Judah was 74,600.
1.28: The sons of Issachar were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
1.29: The number of the family of Issachar was 54,400.
1.30: The sons of Zebulun were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
1.31: The number of the family of Zebulun was 57,400.
1.32: The sons of Joseph, the sons of Ephraim, were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
1.33: The number of the family of Ephraim was 40,500.
1.34: The sons of Manasseh were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
1.35: The number of the family of Manasseh was 32,200.
1.36: The sons of Benjamin were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
1.37: The number of the family of Benjamin was 35,400.
1.38: The sons of Dan were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
1.39: The number of the family of Dan was 62,700.
1.40: The sons of Asher were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
1.41: The number of the family of Asher was 41,500.
1.42: The sons of Naphtali were numbered by their families, by their fathers’ houses, by the number of names. Every male twenty years old and older was numbered, whoever was able to go out to war.
1.43: The number of the family of Naphtali was 53,400.
1.44: These were numbered by Moses and Aaron, and the leaders of Israel, twelve men, each chosen from his father’s house.
1.45: All the men of Israel were numbered by their fathers’ houses, twenty years old and older, whoever in Israel was able to go out to war.
1.46: The number of all the men was 603,550.
1.47: But the Levites by their fathers’ family were not numbered with them.
1.48: For the Lord had told Moses,
1.49: “Only the family of Levi should not be numbered. Do not add their number among the sons of Israel.
1.50: But have the Levites take care of the meeting tent of the Law, and all that is in it, and all that belongs to it. They will carry the meeting tent and all that goes in it. They will take care of it, and set up their tents around it.
1.51: When the meeting tent is to be moved, the Levites will take it down. When the meeting tent is brought to a place to stay, the Levites will set it up. If anyone else comes near, he must be put to death.
1.52: The people of Israel will set up their tents by their own groups and armies, each man by his own flag.
1.53: But the Levites will set up their tents around the meeting tent of the Law. Then no anger will come upon the people of Israel. The Levites must take care of the meeting tent of the Law.”
1.54: So the people of Israel did this. They did everything the Lord had told Moses.

2.1: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
2.2: “The people of Israel will set up their tents, each by his own flag and beside that of their fathers’. They will set up their tents to face the meeting tent on every side.
2.3: Those who stay in their tents on the east side toward the sunrise will have the flag of Judah by their armies. The leader of the people of Judah is Nahshon the son of Amminadab.
2.4: The number of all his army is 74,600.
2.5: The family of Issachar will set up their tents next to Judah. The leader of the people of Issachar is Nethanel the son of Zuar.
2.6: The number of his army is 54,400.
2.7: The family of Zebulun will be next. The leader of the people of Zebulun is Eliab the son of Helon.
2.8: The number of his army is 57,400.
2.9: The whole number among the tents of Judah is 186,400, by their armies. They will be first to move on.
2.10: “On the south side will be the tents of Reuben by their armies with their flags. The leader of the people of Reuben is Elizur the son of Shedeur.
2.11: The number of his army is 46,500.
2.12: The family of Simeon will set up their tents next to him. The leader of the people of Simeon is Shelumiel the son of Zurishaddai.
2.13: The number of his army is 59,300.
2.14: The family of Gad will be next. The leader of the people of Gad is Eliasaph the son of Deuel.
2.15: The number of his army is 45,650.
2.16: The whole number among the tents of Reuben is 151,450 by their armies. They will be second to move on.
2.17: “Then the meeting tent will go out with the Levites among the people. In the same way that they set up their tents, so they will leave to move on, every man in his place, by his flags.
2.18: “On the west side will be the flag of the tents of Ephraim by their armies. The leader of the people of Ephraim is Elishama the son of Ammihud.
2.19: The number of his army is 40,500.
2.20: The family of Manasseh will be next to him. The leader of the people of Manasseh is Gamaliel the son of Pedahzur.
2.21: The number of his army is 32,200.
2.22: The family of Benjamin will be next. The leader of the people of Benjamin is Abidan the son of Gideoni.
2.23: The number of his army is 35,400.
2.24: The whole number among the tents of Ephraim is 108,100, by their armies. They will be third to move on.
2.25: “On the north side will be the flag of the tents of Dan by their armies. The leader of the people of Dan is Ahiezer the son of Ammishaddai.
2.26: The number of his army is 62,700.
2.27: The family of Asher will set up their tents next to him. The leader of the people of Asher is Pagiel the son of Ochran.
2.28: The number of his army is 41,500.
2.29: The family of Naphtali will be next. The leader of the people of Naphtali is Ahira the son of Enan.
2.30: The number of his army is 53,400.
2.31: The whole number among the tents of Dan is 157,600. They will be last to move on with their flags.”
2.32: These are the numbers of the men of Israel by their fathers’ houses. The whole number among all the tents, by their armies, was 603,550.
2.33: But the Levites were not numbered with the people of Israel, just as the Lord had told Moses.
2.34: So the people of Israel did all that the Lord had told Moses. They set up their tents by their flags. And they left to move on in the same way, every one by his family and by his father’s house.

3.1: These are the people of Aaron and Moses at the time when the Lord spoke with Moses on Mount Sinai.
3.2: The names of the sons of Aaron are Nadab the first-born, Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
3.3: These are the names of the sons of Aaron, the chosen religious leaders. Aaron set them apart to work as religious leaders.
3.4: But Nadab and Abihu died before the Lord when they made a fire that was not holy to the Lord in the Desert of Sinai. And they had no children. So Eleazar and Ithamar worked as religious leaders during the life-time of their father Aaron.
3.5: Then the Lord said to Moses,
3.6: “Bring the family of Levi near. Set them in front of Aaron the religious leader so they may serve him.
3.7: They will do the duties for him and for all the people in front of the meeting tent. They will do the work around the meeting tent,
3.8: and will keep all the things that belong to the meeting tent. They will take care of the duties for the people of Israel as they work around the meeting tent.
3.9: You will give the Levites to Aaron and his sons. They are all given to him from among the people of Israel.
3.10: Set apart Aaron and his sons to do the work of religious leaders. But if anyone comes near who is not a religious leader, he must be put to death.”
3.12: “See, I have taken the Levites from among the people of Israel instead of every first-born among the people of Israel. The Levites will be Mine.
3.13: For all the first-born are Mine. On the day that I killed all the first-born in the land of Egypt, I set apart for My own all the first-born in Israel, both man and animal. They will be Mine. I am the Lord.”
3.14: Then the Lord said to Moses in the Desert of Sinai,
3.15: “Number the sons of Levi by their fathers’ houses and by their families. Number every male a month old and older.”
3.16: So Moses numbered them just as he had been told by the word of the Lord.
3.17: The names of the sons of Levi are Gershon, Kohath and Merari.
3.18: The names of the sons of Gershon by their families are Libni and Shimei.
3.19: The sons of Kohath by their families are Amram, Izhar, Hebron and Uzziel.
3.20: The sons of Merari by their families are Mahli and Mushi. These are the families of the Levites by their fathers’ houses.
3.21: Of Gershon were the families of the Libnites and the Shimeites. These were the families of the Gershonites.
3.22: The number of their men, every male a month old and older, was 7,500.
3.23: The families of the Gershonites were to set up their tents behind the meeting tent on the west side.
3.24: The leader of the fathers’ houses of the Gershonites was Eliasaph the son of Lael.
3.25: The sons of Gershon were to take care of the meeting tent, its covering, and the curtain for the door of the meeting tent.
3.26: And they were to take care of the curtains for the door of the open space, and all curtains around the meeting tent and the altar and their ropes. They did all the work having to do with them.
3.27: Of Kohath were the families of the Amramites, the Izharites, the Hebronites and the Uzzielites. These were the families of the Kohathites.
3.28: The number of every male a month old and older was 8,600. They did the duties of the holy place.
3.29: The families of the sons of Kohath were to set up their tents on the south side of the meeting tent.
3.30: The leader of the fathers’ houses of the Kohathite families was Elizaphan the son of Uzziel.
3.31: They took care of the special box with the Law, and the table, the lamp-stand, the altars, the things used in the holy place, and the curtain. They did all the work having to do with them.
3.32: Eleazar, the son of Aaron the religious leader, was the head of the leaders of Levi. He watched over those who did the duties of the holy place.
3.33: Of Merari were the families of the Mahlites and the Mushites. These were the families of Merari.
3.34: The number of their men, every male a month old and older, was 6,200.
3.35: The leader of the fathers’ houses of the families of Merari was Zuriel the son of Abihail. They were to set up their tents on the north side of the meeting tent.
3.36: The duties given to the sons of Merari were to take care of the parts made of wood of the meeting tent, its cross pieces, its pillars, its bases, and all the pieces that had to do with them. They took care of all these things,
3.37: and of the pillars around the open space and their bases and their nails and their ropes.
3.38: Moses and Aaron and his sons were to set up their tents on the east side in front of the meeting tent, toward the sunrise. They did the duties of the meeting tent, whatever had to be done for the people of Israel. But the one who came near who was not a religious leader was to be put to death.
3.39: The number of all the Levite men a month old and older, whom Moses and Aaron numbered by their families as the Lord told them, was 22,000.
3.40: The Lord said to Moses, “Number every first-born male of the sons of Israel a month old and older. Write down their names.
3.41: Take the Levites for Me, instead of all the first-born among the sons of Israel. I am the Lord. And take the cattle of the Levites instead of all the first-born among the cattle of the people of Israel.”
3.42: So Moses numbered all the first-born among the sons of Israel, just as the Lord had told him.
3.43: The number of names of all the first-born males a month old and older was 22,273.
3.44: Then the Lord said to Moses,
3.45: “Take the Levites instead of all the first-born sons of Israel, and the cattle of the Levites. The number of the Levites will be Mine. I am the Lord.
3.46: There are 273 first-born of the sons of Israel, who are more in number than the Levites. You must pay the price for each of them.
3.47: Take five pieces of silver for each, by the weight of silver agreed upon for the meeting tent.
3.48: Give the money, the price of those who are more in number than the Levites, to Aaron and his sons.”
3.49: So Moses took the money to pay for those who were more in number than the Levites.
3.50: He took the money from the first-born sons of Israel, by the weight agreed upon for the meeting tent. He took 1,365 pieces of silver.
3.51: Then Moses gave the money to Aaron and his sons, just as the Lord had told Moses by His Word.

4.1: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
4.2: “Number the sons of Kohath from among the sons of Levi. Number them by their families, by the fathers’ houses,
4.3: from thirty years old and older, even to fifty years old. Number all who are able to do the work in the meeting tent.
4.4: This is the work of the sons of Kohath in the meeting tent to do with the most holy things.
4.5: When the people leave to move on, Aaron and his sons will go in and take down the curtain in front of the special box with the Law inside. And they will cover the special box with it.
4.6: Then they will lay a covering of badgers’ skins on it, and spread a pure blue cloth over that. And they will put in the long pieces of wood to carry it.
4.7: They will spread a blue cloth over the table of the bread before the Lord. They will put on it the plates, the dishes for special perfume, the pots, and the jars for the drink gift. And the bread will be on it always.
4.8: They will spread a red cloth over them, and cover that with badgers’ skins. And they will put in its long pieces of wood to carry it.
4.9: They will take a blue cloth and cover the lamp-stand for the light, with its lamps, its objects to put out the light, its dishes and all its pots of oil used for the light.
4.10: They will put the lamp-stand and all its objects in a covering of badgers’ skins. Then they will put it on the long pieces of wood used to carry it.
4.11: They will spread a blue cloth over the altar of gold, and cover it with badgers’ skins. And they will put in the long pieces of wood to carry it.
4.12: They will take all the things used for the work done in the meeting tent. They will put them in a blue cloth and cover them with a covering of badgers’ skins. And they will put them on the long pieces of wood to carry them.
4.13: Then they will take away the ashes from the altar, and spread a purple cloth over it.
4.14: They will put on it all the things used for the work done on the altar: the fire-holders, meat-hooks, objects for picking up the ashes, and the pots. Then they will spread a covering of badgers’ skins over it, and put in the long pieces of wood for carrying it.
4.15: Aaron and his sons will finish covering the holy objects and all the things of the meeting tent, as the people move on. After that the sons of Kohath will come to carry them. In this way they will not touch the holy objects and die. These are the things in the meeting tent which the sons of Kohath are to carry.
4.16: Eleazar the son of Aaron the religious leader will take care of the oil for the light, the special perfume, the grain gift which is always given, and the oil for holy use. He will watch over all the meeting tent and all that is in it, the holy place and its objects.”
4.17: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
4.18: “Do not let the family group of the Kohathites be destroyed from among the Levites.
4.19: But do this to them so they may live and not die when they come near the most holy objects. Aaron and his sons must go in and give each of them their work and what they are to carry.
4.20: But they must not go in to see the holy objects even for a short time, or they will die.”
4.22: “Number the sons of Gershon also, by their fathers’ houses, by their families.
4.23: Number those who are thirty years old and older, to fifty years old, all who go in to do the work in the meeting tent.
4.24: These are the duties of the families of the Gershonites, in working and in carrying.
4.25: They will carry the curtains of the meeting tent and the meeting tent with its covering and the covering of badgers’ skins that is over it. They will carry the curtain for the door of the meeting tent,
4.26: the curtains of the open space, and the curtain for the gate of the open space which is around the meeting tent and the altar. And they will carry the ropes for the curtains, and all the things used for their work. They will do whatever needs to be done with them.
4.27: All the work of the sons of the Gershonites will be what Aaron and his sons tell them to do. They will tell them what they are to carry and what work they are to do. You will tell them what things they have a duty to carry.
4.28: This is the work to be done by the families of the sons of the Gershonites in the meeting tent. Ithamar the son of Aaron the religious leader will watch over their duties.
4.29: “As for the sons of Merari, number them by their families and by their fathers’ houses.
4.30: Number those who are thirty years old and older, to fifty years old, everyone who goes in to do the work of the meeting tent.
4.31: This is what they are to carry for their work in the meeting tent: the wood pieces of the meeting tent, its cross pieces, pillars and its bases.
4.32: And they are to carry the pillars which are around the open space and their bases and their nails and ropes, with all the things used for their work. You will tell each man by name what he is to carry.
4.33: This is the work of the families of the sons of Merari, all their work in the meeting tent. Ithamar the son of Aaron the religious leader will watch over their duties.”
4.34: So Moses and Aaron and the leaders of the people numbered the sons of the Kohathites by their families and by their fathers’ houses.
4.35: They numbered those who were thirty years old and older, to fifty years old, everyone who went in to do the work in the meeting tent.
4.36: And their number by families was 2,750.
4.37: These are the numbered men of the Kohathite families, everyone who worked in the meeting tent. Moses and Aaron numbered them as the Lord told them to do through Moses.
4.38: The sons of Gershon were numbered, by their families and their fathers’ houses,
4.39: from thirty years old to fifty years old. Everyone who went in to do the work in the meeting tent was numbered.
4.40: And the number of their men by their families and by their fathers’ houses was 2,630.
4.41: These are the numbered men of the families of the sons of Gershon, all who were working in the meeting tent. Moses and Aaron numbered them as the Lord told them to do.
4.42: The men of the families of the sons of Merari were numbered, by their families and their fathers’ houses,
4.43: from thirty years old to fifty years old. Everyone who went in to do the work in the meeting tent was numbered.
4.44: And the number of their men by their families was 3,200.
4.45: These are the numbered men of the families of the sons of Merari. Moses and Aaron numbered them as the Lord told them to do through Moses.
4.46: Moses and Aaron and the leaders of Israel numbered all the men of the Levites by their families and their fathers’ houses,
4.47: from thirty years old to fifty years old. Everyone who could go in to do the work and the carrying of the meeting tent was numbered.
4.48: And the number of their men was 8,580.
4.49: They were each given their work and load to carry, as the Lord told them to do through Moses. So these were his numbered men, just as the Lord had told Moses.

5.2: “Tell the people of Israel to send away from the tents every person with a bad skin disease, every one with a flow that is unclean, and every one who is unclean because of a dead person.
5.3: Send away both male and female. Send them away from the tents so they will not make the place sinful where I live among them.”
5.4: The people of Israel did so. They sent them away from the tents. The people of Israel did just as the Lord had said to Moses.
5.5: Then the Lord said to Moses,
5.6: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘When a man or woman sins the way that man sins by not acting in faith toward the Lord, and that person is guilty,
5.7: then he must tell about the sins he has done. He must pay in full for his wrong-doing, and add one-fifth part to it, and give it to the one he has sinned against.
5.8: But if the man has no brother to whom pay for the wrong can be made, then it must go to the Lord for the religious leader. He must also give a ram to pay for his sins. And his sins will be forgiven.
5.9: Every gift of all the holy things of the Israelites which they bring to the religious leader will become his.
5.10: So every man’s holy gifts will be his. Whatever any man gives to the religious leader will be his.’”
5.12: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘If a man’s wife turns away and is not faithful to him,
5.13: and another man has sex with her and it is hidden from her husband’s eyes, even if it is hidden, she will be unclean. And even if no one speaks against her, because she has not been caught in the act,
5.14: but a spirit of jealousy comes over her husband, he will be jealous of his wife when she has made herself unclean. Or if he becomes jealous of his wife when she has done nothing to make herself unclean,
5.15: then the man must bring his wife to the religious leader. He must bring one-tenth part of a basket of barley as the gift needed for her. He must not pour oil on it. He must not put special perfume on it. For it is a grain gift of jealousy. It is a grain gift to make the sin remembered.
5.16: ‘Then the religious leader will bring her near and have her stand before the Lord.
5.17: The religious leader will take holy water in a clay pot. He will take some of the dust on the floor of the meeting tent and put it into the water.
5.18: Then the religious leader will have the woman stand before the Lord and let the hair of the woman’s head hang loose. He will put the grain gift of remembering into her hands. It is the grain gift of jealousy. In the religious leader’s hand will be the bitter water that can bring a curse to the woman.
5.19: Then the religious leader will have her make a promise. He will say to the woman, “If no man has lain with you and if you have not turned away into sin, while under the power of your husband, this bitter water that brings punishment will not hurt you.
5.20: If you have turned away, while under the power of your husband, and have made yourself unclean by having another man who is not your husband,”
5.21: then the religious leader will have the woman make a promise so she will be punished if she has sinned. He will say to the woman, “May the Lord make you a curse among your people. May the Lord make your leg waste away and your stomach grow bigger.
5.22: This water that brings a curse will go into your stomach and make it grow bigger and your leg to waste away.” And the woman will say, “Let it be so. Let it be so.”
5.23: ‘Then the religious leader will write these curses in a book. And he will wash them off into the bitter water.
5.24: He will make the woman drink the bitter water that brings a curse. The water that brings a curse will go into her and give her pain.
5.25: The religious leader will take the grain gift of jealousy from the woman’s hand. He will wave the grain gift before the Lord and bring it to the altar.
5.26: The religious leader will fill his hand with the grain gift, as the part to be remembered. And he will burn it on the altar. Then he will make the woman drink the water.
5.27: If she has not been faithful to her husband, the water that brings a curse will go into her and give her pain. Her stomach will get larger and her leg will become as dead. A curse will come upon the woman among her people.
5.28: But if the woman has not sinned and is clean, she will be free and able to have children.
5.29: ‘This is the law of jealousy. If a wife who is under the power of her husband turns away and makes herself unclean,
5.30: and a spirit of jealousy comes upon a man, making him jealous of his wife, then he must make the woman stand before the Lord. And the religious leader will do to her all the rules of this Law.
5.31: The husband will be free from guilt. But the woman will carry her guilt.’”

6.1: Then the Lord said to Moses,
6.2: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘A man or woman may make a special promise, the promise of a Nazirite, to set himself apart to the Lord.
6.3: Then he must keep away from wine and strong drink. He will drink no sour wine, made from wine or strong drink. He will not drink any grape drink. And he will not eat new or dried grapes.
6.4: All the days he is set apart, he must not eat anything made from the grape-field, not even the seeds or the skins.
6.5: ‘No hair of his head will be cut, all the days of his promise to be set apart. He must be holy until the time is finished for which he set himself apart to the Lord. He will let the hair on his head grow long.
6.6: ‘All the days he is set apart to the Lord, he must not go near a dead person.
6.7: He must not allow himself to be made unclean when his father, mother, brother or sister die. For he has made a promise to be set apart to God.
6.8: He is holy to the Lord all the days he is set apart.
6.9: ‘But if a man dies next to him, making his hair unclean which had been set apart to the Lord, then he must cut all the hair from his head on the day he is made clean. He will cut it off on the seventh day.
6.10: On the eighth day he must bring two turtle-doves or two young pigeons to the religious leader, to the door of the meeting tent.
6.11: The religious leader will give one for a sin gift and the other for a burnt gift. He will pay for his sin because of the dead person. And he will make his head holy that same day.
6.12: He will set apart to the Lord his days as a Nazirite. And he will bring a year old male lamb for a guilt gift. But the past days will be a loss, because he had become unclean during the time he was set apart.
6.13: ‘This is the Law of the Nazirite when the time he is set apart is finished. He must bring the gift to the door of the meeting tent.
6.14: He will give his gift to the Lord. It will be a perfect male lamb a year old for a burnt gift, one perfect female lamb a year old for a sin gift, and one perfect ram for a peace gift.
6.15: And he will give a basket of bread made of fine flour mixed with oil, made without yeast. He will give hard bread spread with oil and made without yeast. With them he will give their grain gift and drink gifts.
6.16: Then the religious leader will give all these to the Lord and his sin gift and his burnt gift.
6.17: He will also give the ram for peace gifts to the Lord, together with the basket of bread made without yeast. Then the religious leader will give its grain gift and drink gift.
6.18: Then at the door of the meeting tent the Nazirite will cut off the hair that has been set apart for holy use. He is to take the hair and put it in the fire under the peace gifts.

6.20: The religious leader will wave them for a wave gift before the Lord. They are holy and belong to the religious leader, together with the breast given as a wave gift and the thigh given by lifting it up. After that the Nazirite may drink wine.’
6.21: “This is the Law of the Nazirite who makes a promise to give to the Lord what he promised as a Nazirite, and whatever else he is able to give. He must do what he has promised by the Law of being set apart as a Nazirite.”
6.22: Then the Lord said to Moses,
6.23: “Say to Aaron and his sons, ‘This is the way you should bring good to the people of Israel. Say to them,
6.24: “May the Lord bring good to you and keep you.
6.25: May the Lord make His face shine upon you, and be kind to you.
6.26: May the Lord show favor toward you, and give you peace.”’
6.27: So they will put My name upon the people of Israel, and I will bring good to them.”

8.2: “Say to Aaron, ‘When you put the seven lamps on the lamp-stand, they should give light in front of the lamp-stand.’”
8.3: And Aaron did so. He put the lamps so they would give light in front of the lamp-stand, as the Lord had told Moses.
8.4: Now this is the way the lamp-stand was made. It was made of beaten gold from the base to its flowers. He made the lamp-stand the way the Lord had shown Moses.
8.5: Then the Lord said to Moses,
8.6: “Take the Levites from among the people of Israel, and make them clean.
8.7: To make them clean, put holy water on them that takes away sin. Let them cut all the hair from their body, and wash their clothes, and they shall be clean.
8.8: Then let them take a young bull and its grain gift of fine flour mixed with oil. Take another young bull for a sin gift.
8.9: Bring the Levites in front of the meeting tent and gather together all the people of Israel also.
8.10: Bring the Levites before the Lord and the people of Israel will lay their hands on the Levites.
8.11: Aaron will give the Levites to the Lord as a wave gift from the people of Israel so they will be able to do the work of the Lord.
8.12: The Levites will lay their hands on the heads of the bulls. They will give one for a sin gift and the other for a burnt gift to the Lord, to pay for the sins of the Levites.
8.13: Then have the Levites stand in front of Aaron and his sons, to give them as a wave gift to the Lord.
8.14: “So you will divide the Levites from the people of Israel. And the Levites will be Mine.
8.15: After that the Levites may go in to work in the meeting tent. But you must make them clean and give them as a wave gift.
8.16: For they are all given to Me from among the people of Israel. I have taken them for Myself instead of every first child to be born, the first-born of all the people of Israel.
8.17: For every first-born among the people of Israel is Mine, both of man and animal. I set them apart for Myself on the day that I killed all the first-born in the land of Egypt.
8.18: But I have taken the Levites instead of every first-born among the people of Israel.
8.19: And I have given the Levites as a gift to Aaron and his sons from among the people of Israel. They will do the work of the people of Israel at the meeting tent. By this they take away the sins of the people of Israel. So no trouble will come upon the people of Israel if they come near the meeting tent.”
8.20: Moses and Aaron and all the people of Israel did this to the Levites. The people of Israel did to them all the things the Lord had told Moses about the Levites.
8.21: The Levites made themselves pure, putting away their sin. And they washed their clothes. Aaron gave them as a wave gift before the Lord. He did what had to be done to pay for their sin so they would be clean.
8.22: After that the Levites went in to do their work in the meeting tent in front of Aaron and his sons. So they did to the Levites just what the Lord had told Moses to do.
8.24: “This is the rule for the Levites. Those who are twenty-five years old and older will go in to do the work of the meeting tent.
8.25: But when they are fifty years old they will stop these duties and not work any more.
8.26: They may help their brothers in the meeting tent to do what needs to be done but they themselves must not do the work. These are the rules for the Levites when giving them their duties.”

9.1: The Lord spoke to Moses in the Sinai desert, in the first month of the second year after they had come out of the land of Egypt. The Lord said,
9.2: “Let the people of Israel keep the Passover at the time given for it.
9.3: Keep it at its given time, in the evening of the fourteenth day of this month. Keep it by obeying all its Laws.”
9.4: So Moses told the people of Israel to keep the Passover.
9.5: And they kept the Passover in the evening of the fourteenth day of the first month, in the Sinai desert. The people of Israel did all that the Lord had told Moses.
9.6: But there were some men who were unclean because they had touched a dead person. So they could not keep the Passover on that day. They came to Moses and Aaron that day
9.7: and said to Moses, “We are unclean because we touched a dead person. But why are we kept from giving the Lord’s gift at its given time among the people of Israel?”
9.8: Moses said to them, “Wait, and I will listen to what the Lord will tell me to do with you.”
9.9: Then the Lord said to Moses,
9.10: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘If anyone of you or your children touch a dead person and become unclean, or if you are traveling far away, even so, he may still keep the Passover to the Lord.
9.11: They will keep it in the evening of the fourteenth day of the second month. They will eat it with bread without yeast and with bitter tasting plants.
9.12: They must not leave any of it until morning. And they must not break a bone of the lamb. They must obey all of the Law of the Passover.
9.13: But if a man is clean and is not away traveling, yet does not keep the Passover, he must be cut off from his people. For he did not give the Lord’s gift at the time he was to do so. That man will be guilty of his sin.
9.14: If a stranger staying with you wants to keep the Passover to the Lord and obey the Law of the Passover, he may do so. You will have one law, both for the stranger and for the one who was born in the land.’”
9.15: On the day that the meeting tent was set up, the cloud covered the meeting tent, the tent of the law. In the evening it was over the meeting tent. It looked like fire until morning.
9.16: It was like this always. The cloud would cover it during the day. What looked like fire would cover it during the night.
9.17: When the cloud was lifted from over the meeting tent, the people of Israel would move on. Where the cloud rested, there the people of Israel would set up their tents.
9.18: The people of Israel would move on as the Lord told them. And they would set up their tents as the Lord told them. They stayed in one place as long as the cloud rested over the meeting tent.
9.19: Even when the cloud rested over the meeting tent for many days, the people of Israel would obey the Lord and not leave.
9.20: Sometimes the cloud stayed a few days over the meeting tent. But they obeyed the Lord and stayed in that place. Then they would leave when the Lord told them.
9.21: Sometimes the cloud stayed from evening until morning. When the cloud lifted in the morning, they would leave. If the cloud stayed during the day and the night, when it was lifted, they would leave that place.
9.22: Even when the cloud stayed over the meeting tent for two days, or a month, or a year the people of Israel would stay in that place and not leave. They would leave when it was lifted.
9.23: They set up their tents as the Lord told them. And they moved on as the Lord told them. They obeyed what the Lord had told them to do through Moses.

10.2: “Make two silver horns of beaten silver. Use them for calling the people together and for having the people move on.
10.3: When both horns sound, all the people will gather in front of you at the door of the meeting tent.
10.4: If only one horn sounds, then the leaders, the heads of the families of Israel, will gather in front of you.
10.5: When you blow the horn to tell of danger, the people whose tents are on the east side will leave.
10.6: When you blow the horn to tell of danger a second time, the people whose tents are on the south side will leave. A horn telling of danger will be blown when they are to move on.
10.7: But when the people are to be gathered together, you will blow the horn without the sound of danger.
10.8: Aaron’s sons, the religious leaders, will blow the horns. This will be a Law for all your people forever.
10.9: When you go to war in your land against those who fight you, then sound the horns to tell of war. That way you will be remembered before the Lord your God, and be saved from those who hate you.
10.10: On the days you are glad and at the time of your special suppers and on the first days of your months, blow the horns. Blow the horns over your burnt gifts and over your peace gifts. Then you will be remembered before your God. I am the Lord your God.”
10.11: On the twentieth day of the second month in the second year, the cloud was lifted from over the meeting tent of the Law.
10.12: The people of Israel moved on from the Desert of Sinai. Then the cloud came down and rested in the desert of Paran.
10.13: So they moved for the first time as the Lord had told them through Moses.
10.14: The flag of the people of Judah left first, by their armies. Amminadab’s son Nahshon was the head of their army.
10.15: Zuar’s son Nethanel was the head of the men of Issachar.
10.16: And Helon’s son Eliab was the head of the men of Zebulun.
10.17: When the meeting tent was taken down, the sons of Gershon and Merari left carrying it.
10.18: Next the flag of the people of Reuben left, by their armies. Shedeur’s son Elizur was the head over this army.
10.19: Zurishaddai’s son Shelumiel was the head of the men of Simeon.
10.20: Deuel’s son Eliasaph was the head of the men of Gad.
10.21: Then the Kohathites left, carrying the holy objects. The meeting tent was set up before they came to the next place.
10.22: Next the flag of the people of Ephraim left, by their armies. Ammihud’s son Elishama was the head over this army.
10.23: Pedahzur’s son Gamaliel was the head of the men of Manasseh.
10.24: Gideoni’s son Abidan was the head of the men of Benjamin.
10.25: Then the flag of the people of Dan left, by their armies. They followed behind all the people of Israel, to watch for danger. Ammishaddai’s son Ahiezer was the head over this army.
10.26: Ochran’s son Pagiel was the head of the men of Asher.
10.27: And Enan’s son Ahira was the head of the men of Naphtali.
10.28: This was how the people of Israel moved on by their armies.
10.29: Then Moses said to Hobab the son of Reuel the Midianite, Moses’ father-in-law, “We are going to the place the Lord said He will give to us. Come with us and we will do you good. For the Lord has promised good to Israel.”
10.30: But Hobab said to him, “I will not come. I will go to my own land and family.”
10.31: Moses said, “I beg you, do not leave us. For you know where we should stay in the desert. You will be like eyes for us.
10.32: If you go with us, we will do for you whatever good the Lord does for us.”
10.33: So they traveled for three days from the mountain of the Lord with the special box with the Law of the Lord in front of them looking for a place for them to rest.
10.34: The cloud of the Lord was over them during the day, when they moved on.
10.35: When the special box of the Lord moved on, Moses said, “Rise up, O Lord! Let those who hate You be divided. Let those who hate You run away before You.”
10.36: And when it rested, he said, “Return, O Lord, to the many thousands of Israel.”

11.1: Now the people complained about their troubles in the hearing of the Lord. When the Lord heard it, His anger burned. The fire of the Lord burned among them, and destroyed some around the outer parts of the tents.
11.2: Then the people cried to Moses and he prayed to the Lord, and the fire went out.
11.3: So the name of that place was called Taberah, because the fire of the Lord burned among them.
11.4: The mixed group of people among them had strong desires. The people of Israel cried again and said, “Who will give us meat to eat?
11.5: We remember all the fish we could eat free in Egypt, and all the fruit and vegetables and spices.
11.6: But now our strength is gone. There is nothing at all to look at except this bread from heaven.”
11.7: Now the bread from heaven was like coriander seed, and it looked like bdellium.
11.8: The people would go and gather it and beat it between stones. They boiled it in a pot or made bread with it. It tasted like bread made with oil.
11.9: When the grass became wet around the tents at night, the bread from heaven would fall.
11.10: Moses heard all the people crying in every family, each man at the door of his tent. The Lord became very angry with them and Moses was not pleased.
11.11: So Moses said to the Lord, “Why have You been so hard on Your servant? Why have I not found favor in Your eyes, that You have laid the troubles of all these people on me?
11.12: Did I give birth to all these people? Did I bring them out, that You should say to me, ‘Carry them close to your heart as a nurse carries a nursing baby, to the land You promised their fathers’?
11.13: Where am I to get meat to give to all these people? They cry in front of me, saying, ‘Give us meat so we may eat!’
11.14: I am not able to carry all these people alone. The load is too heavy for me.
11.15: So if You are going to act this way toward me, I beg You to kill me now, if I have found favor in Your eyes. Do not let me see how bad off I am.”
11.16: The Lord said to Moses, “Gather for Me seventy men from the leaders of Israel, whom you know to be the leaders of the people, the men who rule over them. Bring them to the meeting tent and let them stand there with you.
11.17: Then I will come down and speak with you there. I will take of the Spirit Who is upon you, and will put Him upon them. Then they will carry the troubles of the people with you so you will not carry them all alone.
11.18: Say to the people, ‘Make yourselves holy for tomorrow, and you will eat meat. The Lord heard you when you cried and said, “If only someone would give us meat to eat! For it was well with us in Egypt.” So the Lord will give you meat and you will eat.
11.19: You will not eat it for only one day, or two days, or five days, or ten days, or twenty days.
11.20: But you will eat it a whole month, until it comes out of your nose and you hate it, because you have turned away from the Lord Who is among you. You have cried before Him, saying, “Why did we ever leave Egypt?”’”
11.21: But Moses said, “The people whom I am among are 600,000 on foot. And You have said, ‘I will give them meat so they may eat for a whole month.’
11.22: Will enough flocks and cattle be killed to feed them? Or will enough fish be gathered from the sea to feed them?”
11.23: The Lord said to Moses, “Is there an end to the Lord’s power? Now you will see if My Word will come true for you or not.”
11.24: So Moses went out and told the people the words of the Lord. And he gathered seventy men from the leaders of the people, and had them stand around the meeting tent.
11.25: Then the Lord came down in the cloud and spoke to him. He took of the Spirit Who was upon him and put Him upon the seventy leaders. When the Spirit rested upon them, they spoke the word of the Lord. But they did not do it again.
11.26: But two men had stayed among the tents. Their names were Eldad and Medad, and the Spirit rested upon them. They were among those who had been chosen, but had not gone out to the meeting tent. So they spoke the word of the Lord among the tents.
11.27: A young man ran and told Moses, “Eldad and Medad are speaking the word of the Lord among the tents.”
11.28: Then Joshua the son of Nun, the helper of Moses since he was young, said, “Moses, my lord, do not let them.”
11.29: But Moses said to him, “Are you jealous for my good? If only all the Lord’s people would speak for God, that the Lord would put His Spirit upon them!”
11.30: Then Moses and the leaders of Israel returned to the tents.
11.31: Now a wind went out from the Lord. It brought quail from the sea, and let them fall beside the place where the tents were set up. They fell all around the tents, about as far on each side as it takes to travel in a day. They lay on the ground as deep as two cubits.
11.32: The people worked all day and all night and all the next day gathering the quail. He who gathered the least gathered enough to fill 110 baskets. And they spread them out for themselves all around the tents.
11.33: While the meat was still between their teeth and not yet eaten, the Lord became angry with the people. The Lord sent a bad sickness upon the people.
11.34: So the name of that place was called Kibroth-hattaavah. Because there they buried the people who had wanted meat to eat.
11.35: The people left Kibroth-hattaavah and went to Hazeroth. And they stayed at Hazeroth.

12.1: Miriam and Aaron spoke against Moses because of his Cushite wife, for he had married a Cushite woman.
12.2: They said, “Is it true that the Lord has spoken only through Moses? Has He not spoken through us also?” And the Lord heard it.
12.3: Now Moses was a man with no pride, more so than any man on the earth.
12.4: At once the Lord said to Moses and Aaron and Miriam, “You three come out to the meeting tent.” So the three of them came out.
12.5: Then the Lord came down in a cloud and stood at the door of the meeting tent, and called Aaron and Miriam. When both of them had come near,
12.6: the Lord said, “Now listen to Me. If there is a man who speaks for God among you, I the Lord will make Myself known to him in a special dream. I will speak with him in a dream.
12.7: Not so, with My servant Moses. He is faithful in all My house.
12.8: With him I speak face to face in ways he understands, and not in ways he does not understand. And he sees what the Lord is like. Why then were you not afraid to speak against My servant Moses?”
12.9: The Lord was angry with them, and He left.
12.10: When the cloud lifted from over the meeting tent, Miriam had a very bad skin disease. She was as white as snow. Aaron turned toward Miriam and saw that she had a bad skin disease.
12.11: Then Aaron said to Moses, “O, my lord, I beg you. Do not punish us because we have been foolish and have sinned.
12.12: Let her not be like one who is dead, whose flesh is half eaten away when he is born!”‘
12.13: And Moses cried to the Lord, saying, “O God, heal her, I pray!”
12.14: But the Lord said to Moses, “If her father had only spit in her face, would she not carry her shame for seven days? Let her be shut up for seven days away from the tents. After that, she may be brought in again.”
12.15: So Miriam was shut up away from the tents for seven days. And the people did not travel on until Miriam was brought in again.
12.16: The people moved from Hazeroth after that. And they set up their tents in the desert of Paran.

13.2: “Send men to spy out the land of Canaan which I am going to give to the people of Israel. Send a man from each of their fathers’ families, every one a leader among them.”
13.3: So Moses sent them from the desert of Paran, as the Lord had told him. All of the men were heads of the people of Israel.
13.4: These were their names. There was Shammua the son of Zaccur from the family of Reuben,
13.5: Shaphat the son of Hori from the family of Simeon,
13.6: Caleb the son of Jephunneh from the family of Judah,
13.7: and Igal the son of Joseph from the family of Issachar.
13.8: There was Hoshea the son of Nun from the family of Ephraim,
13.9: Palti the son of Raphu from the family of Benjamin,
13.10: Gaddiel the son of Sodi from the family of Zebulun,
13.11: and Gaddi the son of Susi from the family of Joseph, from the family of Manasseh.
13.12: There was Ammiel the son of Gemalli from the family of Dan,
13.13: Sethur the son of Michael from the family of Asher,
13.14: Nahbi the son of Vophsi from the family of Naphtali,
13.15: and Geuel the son of Machi from the family of Gad.
13.16: These are the names of the men whom Moses sent to spy out the land. But Moses called Hoshea the son of Nun, Joshua.
13.17: Moses sent them to spy out the land of Canaan. He said to them, “Go up there into the Negev. Then go up into the hill country.
13.18: See what the land is like. See if the people who live in it are strong or weak, and if they are few or many.
13.19: Find out if the land they live in is good or bad. See if the cities they live in are open or if they have walls.
13.20: Find out if the land is rich or poor, and if there are trees in it or not. Then try to get some of the fruit of the land.” Now this was the gathering time of the first grown grapes.
13.21: So they went up and spied out the land from the Desert of Zin as far as Rehob, at Lebo-hamath.
13.22: When they had gone up into the Negev, they came to Hebron. Anak’s sons Ahiman, Sheshai and Talmai were there. (Hebron was built seven years before Zoan in Egypt.)
13.23: Then they came to the valley of Eshcol. They cut down a branch from there with some grapes on it. And they carried it on a long piece of wood between two men, with some pomegranates and figs.
13.24: That place was called the valley of Eshcol, because of much fruit the men of Israel cut down from there.
13.25: They returned from looking over the land after forty days.
13.26: And they came to Moses and Aaron and to all the people of Israel in the desert of Paran, at Kadesh. They brought news to them and to all the people, and showed them the fruit of the land.
13.27: They told Moses, “We went to the land where you sent us. It does flow with milk and honey. This is its fruit.
13.28: But the people who live in the land are strong. The cities have walls and are very large. And we saw the children of Anak there.
13.29: Amalek is living in the land of the Negev. The Hittites and Jebusites and Amorites are living in the hill country. And the Canaanites are living by the sea and by the side of the Jordan.”
13.30: Then Caleb told the people in front of Moses to be quiet. And he said, “Let us go up at once and take the land. For we are well able to take it in battle.”
13.31: But the men who had gone up with him said, “We are not able to go against the people. They are too strong for us.”
13.32: So they brought the people of Israel bad news about the land they had spied out, saying, “The land we have gone to spy out is a land that destroys those who go there to live. All the people we saw in it are very large.
13.33: We saw the Nephilim there. (The sons of Anak are part of the Nephilim.) We looked like grasshoppers in our own eyes, and we looked the same to them.”

14.1: Then all the people cried out with a loud voice, and they cried that night.
14.2: All the people of Israel complained against Moses and Aaron, and said to them, “If only we had died in the land of Egypt! Or if only we had died in this desert!
14.3: Why is the Lord bringing us into this land to be killed by the sword? Our wives and our little ones will be taken away. Would it not be better for us to return to Egypt?”
14.4: So they said to one another, “Let us choose a leader and return to Egypt.”
14.5: Then Moses and Aaron fell on their faces in front of all the gathering of the people of Israel.
14.6: And Joshua the son of Nun and Caleb the son of Jephunneh tore their clothes. They were among those who had spied out the land.
14.7: They said to all the people of Israel, “The land we passed through to spy out is a very good land.
14.8: If the Lord is pleased with us, then He will bring us into this land and give it to us. It is a land which flows with milk and honey.
14.9: Only do not go against the Lord. And do not be afraid of the people of the land. For they will be our food. They have no way to keep safe, and the Lord is with us. Do not be afraid of them.”
14.10: But all the people said to throw stones at Joshua and Caleb. Then the shining-greatness of the Lord was seen in the meeting tent by all the people of Israel.
14.11: The Lord said to Moses, “How long will this people turn away from Me? How long will they not believe in Me, even after all the great works I have done among them?
14.12: I will punish them with disease, and will not give them the land. And I will make you into a nation greater and stronger than they.”
14.13: But Moses said to the Lord, “Then the Egyptians will hear of it. For You brought this people here by Your strength from among them.
14.14:
And they will tell the people who live in this land. They have heard
that You, O Lord, are with these people and that You, O Lord, are seen face to face as Your cloud is over them. You go before them in a cloud during the day, and in fire during the night.
14.15: Now if You kill these people as one man, the nations who have heard how great You are will say,
14.16: ‘The Lord was not able to bring these people into the land He promised to give them. So He has killed them in the desert.’
14.17: But now, I pray, let the power of the Lord be great as You have promised, saying,
14.18: ‘The Lord is slow to anger and filled with loving-kindness, forgiving sin and wrong-doing. But He will not let the guilty go without being punished. He brings the sin of fathers down upon the children, even the great-grandchildren.’
14.19: I pray that You will forgive the sin of this people by the greatness of Your loving-kindness. Forgive them as You have forgiven them from Egypt until now.”
14.20: So the Lord said, “I have forgiven them as you asked.
14.21: But for sure, as I live, all the earth will be filled with the shining-greatness of the Lord.
14.22: All the men who have seen My greatness and My wonderful works which I did in Egypt and in the desert but have put Me to the test these ten times and have not listened to My voice, for sure, they
14.23: will not see the land I promised to their fathers. None of those who have turned away from Me will see it.
14.24: But My servant Caleb has had a different spirit and has followed Me in every way. I will bring him into the land where he went, and his children will take it for themselves.
14.25: Now the Amalekites and the Canaanites live in the valleys. So turn tomorrow and move on to the desert by the way of the Red Sea.”
14.26: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
14.27: “How long will these sinful people speak against Me? I have heard the people of Israel complaining against Me.
14.28: Say to them, ‘As I live, what you have said in My hearing I will do to you,’ says the Lord.
14.29: ‘Your dead bodies will fall in this desert, all of you who were numbered from twenty years old and older, who have spoken against Me.
14.30: For sure, not one will go into the land where I promised to have you live, except Caleb the son of Jephunneh and Joshua the son of Nun.
14.31: You said that your children would be taken and killed. But I will bring them in, and they will know the land you have turned away from.
14.32: But as for you, your dead bodies will fall in this desert.
14.33: Your children will be shepherds in the desert for forty years. They will suffer because you were not faithful, until your dead bodies lie in the desert.
14.34: You spied out the land for forty days. For each day you will carry your guilt a year, forty years. And you will know that I am against you.
14.35: I the Lord have spoken. For sure I will do this to all these sinful people who are gathered together against Me. They will be destroyed in this desert. And there they will die.’”
14.36: Moses had sent men to spy out the land. They returned and made all the people complain against him by bringing bad news about the land.
14.37: These men who brought the very bad news about the land died of a disease before the Lord.
14.38: But Joshua the son of Nun and Caleb the son of Jephunneh stayed alive, of those men who went to spy out the land.
14.39: When Moses told these words to all the people of Israel, the people were filled with much sorrow.
14.40: They got up early in the morning and went up to the top of the hill country, saying, “Here we are. It is true we have sinned. But we will go up to the place which the Lord has promised.”
14.41: But Moses said, “Why now do you sin against the Word of the Lord? It will not get you what you want.
14.42: Do not go up, or you will be killed by those who fight against you. For the Lord is not with you.
14.43: The Amalekites and the Canaanites will be there in front of you, and you will be killed by the sword. Because you have turned away from following the Lord, the Lord will not be with you.”
14.44: But they would not listen and went up to the top of the hill country. The special box with the Law of the Lord, and Moses, did not leave the tents.
14.45: Then the Amalekites and the Canaanites who lived in that hill country came down and went against them and beat them down as far as Hormah.

15.2: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘When you go into the land where you are to live, which I am giving you,
15.3: then give a gift in worship by fire to the Lord. Give a gift from the herd or the flock, a burnt gift, or a gift to keep a special promise, or a free-will gift, or one during special suppers. This will be to make a pleasing smell to the Lord.
15.4: The one who brings his gift will bring to the Lord a grain gift of one-tenth part of a basket of fine flour mixed with one-fourth part of a large jar of oil.
15.5: And make ready one-fourth part of a large jar of wine to pour over the burnt gift or for each lamb given on the altar in worship.
15.6: Or for a ram, make ready a grain gift of two-tenths part of a basket of fine flour mixed with one-third part of a large jar of oil.
15.7: Then make one-third part of a large jar of wine for the drink gift, a pleasing smell to the Lord.
15.8: You may make ready a bull for a burnt gift or give an animal on the altar in worship, to keep a special promise, or give peace gifts to the Lord.
15.9: With the bull bring a grain gift of three-tenths part of a basket of fine flour mixed with half a large jar of oil.
15.10: Bring for the drink gift half a large jar of wine, as a gift by fire, a pleasing smell to the Lord.
15.11: ‘It must be done this way for each bull, or for each ram, or for each of the male lambs or young goats.
15.12: Whatever number you make ready, you must do for everyone.
15.13: All who are born in the land must do these things in this way by giving a gift by fire, a pleasing smell to the Lord.
15.14: A stranger staying with you, or a man living among your people, may want to give a gift by fire, a pleasing smell to the Lord. Then he must do just as you do.
15.15: There will be one Law for you and for the stranger who stays with you. It will be a Law forever for all your children-to-come. As you are, so will the stranger be before the Lord.
15.16: One Law will be for you and for the stranger who stays with you.’”
15.17: Then the Lord said to Moses,
15.18: “Say to the people of Israel, ‘When you come into the land where I bring you
15.19: and when you eat of the food of the land, you must lift up a gift in worship to the Lord.
15.20: Give a loaf of bread as a gift from the first of your grain. Give it as the gift of the grain-floor.
15.21: From the first of your grain you and all your children-to-come must give a gift to the Lord.
15.22: ‘Without knowing it you might not obey all these Laws which the Lord has spoken to Moses,
15.23: even all that the Lord has told you to do through Moses, from the day when the Lord told you and through all your children-to-come.
15.24: If this is done without the people knowing it, then all the people must give one bull for a burnt gift. It will be a pleasing smell to the Lord. It must be brought with its grain gift and its drink gift, by the Law, and with one male goat for a sin gift.
15.25: Then the religious leader will pay for the sins of all the people of Israel, and they will be forgiven. Because it was a mistake, they brought their gift, a gift by fire to the Lord, and their sin gift to the Lord, for their mistake.
15.26: So all the people of Israel and the stranger who stays among them will be forgiven. For it happened to all the people by mistake.
15.27: ‘If one person sins without knowing it, he must bring a one year old female goat for a sin gift.
15.28: And the religious leader before the Lord will pay for the sin of the person who sins without knowing it. He will pay for his sin so he may be forgiven.
15.29: You will have one Law for him who does anything without knowing it, for him who is one of the people of Israel and for the stranger who lives among them.
15.30: But if a person born in the land or a stranger does anything wrong and means to do it, he is speaking against the Lord. That person must be cut off from among his people.
15.31: Because he has hated the Word of the Lord and has broken His Law, that person must be cut off for sure. His guilt will be on him.’”
15.32: While the people of Israel were in the desert, they found a man gathering wood on the Day of Rest.
15.33: Those who found him gathering wood brought him to Moses and Aaron, and to all the people.
15.34: They put him in chains, because they did not know what should be done to him for gathering wood on the Day of Rest.
15.35: Then the Lord said to Moses: “The man must be put to death. All the people must kill him with stones away from the tents.”
15.36: So all the people took him away from the tents and killed him with stones, just as the Lord had told Moses.
15.38: “Speak to the people of Israel. Tell them that they and all their children-to-come are to make tassels for themselves on the corners of their clothing. And they are to put a blue rope on the tassel of each corner.
15.39: It will be a tassel for you to look at and remember all the Laws of the Lord, and to do them. Do not follow your own heart and your own eyes, as you did when you acted like a woman selling the use of her body.
15.40: It will be so that you may remember to obey all My Laws, and be holy to your God.
15.41: I am the Lord your God Who brought you out from the land of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord your God.”

16.1: Now Korah the son of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, with Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, and On the son of Peleth, sons of Reuben, caused trouble.
16.2: They came in front of Moses, together with some of the sons of Israel. They had chosen 250 leaders of the people of Israel, well-known men.
16.3: They all gathered together against Moses and Aaron, and said to them, “You have gone too far! For all the people are holy, every one of them, and the Lord is among them. So why do you honor yourselves more than the people of the Lord?”
16.4: When Moses heard this, he bowed to the ground.
16.5: He said to Korah and all who were with him, “Tomorrow morning the Lord will show who is His, and who is holy. He will have him come near to Him. He will bring near to Himself the one whom He will choose.
16.6: Do this, Korah and all who are with you. Take pots for burning special perfume.
16.7: Put fire in them, and put special perfume upon them before the Lord tomorrow. The man whom the Lord chooses will be the one who is holy. You have gone too far, you sons of Levi!”
16.8: Then Moses said to Korah, “Hear now, you sons of Levi.
16.9: Is it not enough for you that the God of Israel has set you apart from the rest of the people of Israel? He has brought you near to Himself. He has you do the work around the meeting tent of the Lord. And He has you stand in front of the people to care for them.
16.10: He has brought you near to Him, Korah, and all your brothers who are the sons of Levi, with you. Would you try to be the religious leaders also?
16.11: So you and all who are with you are gathered together against the Lord. But as for Aaron, who is he that you complain against him?”
16.12: Then Moses sent to call Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab. But they said, “We will not come up.
16.13: Is it not enough that you have brought us up out of a land flowing with milk and honey to have us die in the desert? Must you make yourself a ruler over us also?
16.14: More than this, you have not brought us into a land flowing with milk and honey. You have not given us any land with fields and grape vines. Would you put out the eyes of these men? We will not come up!”
16.15: Moses became very angry. He said to the Lord, “Do not respect their gift! I have not taken one donkey from them. And I have not hurt one of them.”
16.16: Then Moses said to Korah, “You and all who are with you be before the Lord tomorrow, you and they, and Aaron.
16.17: Each of you take his fire pot and put special perfume on it. And each of you bring his fire pot before the Lord, 250 fire pots. Let both you and Aaron bring his fire pot also.”
16.18: So each man took his fire pot and put fire in it and put special perfume on it. And they stood at the door of the meeting tent with Moses and Aaron.
16.19: Korah gathered together all the people against them at the door of the meeting tent. And the shining-greatness of the Lord was seen by all the people.
16.20: The Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
16.21: “Go away from these people, so I may destroy them at once.”
16.22: But they fell on their faces, and said, “O God, the God of the spirits of all flesh, when one man sins, will You be angry with all the people?”
16.23: Then the Lord said to Moses,
16.24: “Say to the people, ‘Get away from the tents of Korah, Dathan and Abiram.’”
16.25: Then Moses got up and went to Dathan and Abiram, with the leaders of Israel following him.
16.26: And he said to the people, “Go away now from the tents of these sinful men. Touch nothing that belongs to them, or you will be destroyed because of all their sin.”
16.27: So they went away from the tents of Korah, Dathan and Abiram. And Dathan and Abiram came out and stood at the door of their tents, with their wives, their sons, and their little ones.
16.28: Moses said, “By this you will know that the Lord has sent me to do all these works. For this is not my doing.
16.29: If these men die in the same way all men die, or if what happens to everyone happens to them, then the Lord has not sent me.
16.30: But the Lord will do something new. The ground will open its mouth and take them with all that belongs to them. And they will go down alive into the place of the dead. Then you will understand that these men have turned against the Lord.”
16.31: As soon as he stopped speaking, the ground under them opened up.
16.32: The earth opened its mouth and took them and all those of their house, and all Korah’s men and all that belonged to them.
16.33: They and all that belonged to them went down alive to the place of the dead, and the earth closed over them. They were destroyed from among the people.
16.34: And all Israel who were around them ran away at their cry. For they said, “The earth may take us too!”
16.35: Then fire came from the Lord and destroyed the 250 men who had brought the special perfume.
16.37: “Tell Eleazar the son of Aaron the religious leader to take the fire pots out of the fire. For they are holy. Then spread the burning pieces far apart.
16.38: Let the fire pots of these men who have sinned and lost their lives be made into beaten plates to cover the altar. For they did bring them to the Lord and they are holy. They will be something special for the people of Israel to see.”
16.39: So Eleazar the religious leader took the brass fire pots which the men who were burned had brought. And they beat them into plates to cover the altar.
16.40: They were to make the people of Israel remember that no man who is not a religious leader and a son of Aaron should come to burn special perfume before the Lord. Or he might become like Korah and those who were with him, as the Lord said to Eleazar through Moses.
16.41: But on the next day all the people of Israel complained against Moses and Aaron, saying, “You are the ones who have caused the death of the Lord’s people.”
16.42: When the people had gathered against Moses and Aaron, they turned toward the meeting tent. There the cloud covered it and they saw the shining-greatness of the Lord.
16.43: Then Moses and Aaron came to the front of the meeting tent.
16.44: And the Lord said to Moses,
16.45: “Get away from these people, so I may destroy them at once.” Then they fell on their faces.
16.46: Moses said to Aaron, “Take your fire pot and put fire in it from the altar, and lay special perfume on it. Then be quick to bring it to the people and pay for their sin. For anger has gone out from the Lord. The disease has come!”
16.47: So Aaron took it as Moses said, and ran to the people. The disease had already come upon them. He put on the special perfume and paid for the sin of the people.
16.48: He stood between the dead and the living, and the disease was stopped.
16.49: But 14,700 people died by the disease, as well as those who died because of Korah.
16.50: Then Aaron returned to Moses at the door of the meeting tent, for the disease had been stopped.

17.2: “Speak to the people of Israel. Get walking sticks from them, one for each father’s house. Get twelve walking sticks, from all their leaders by their fathers’ houses. Write each man’s name on his stick.
17.3: Write Aaron’s name on the walking stick of Levi. For there will be one walking stick for the head of each father’s house.
17.4: Then put them in the meeting tent before the Law, where I meet with you.
17.5: And the walking stick of the man I choose will begin to grow. In this way I will stop the complaining of the people of Israel, who are complaining against you.”
17.6: So Moses spoke to the people of Israel. All their leaders each gave him a walking stick, one for each leader by their fathers’ houses, twelve walking sticks. And the walking stick of Aaron was among their walking sticks.
17.7: Moses put the walking sticks before the Lord in the meeting tent of the Law.
17.8: The next day Moses went into the meeting tent of the Law. And he saw that the walking stick of Aaron for the house of Levi had begun to grow buds and flowers and almonds.
17.9: Moses brought out all the walking sticks from before the Lord to all the people of Israel. They looked, and each man took his stick.
17.10: But the Lord said to Moses, “Put the walking stick of Aaron in front of the Law again. It will be something special to see against those who go against My Word. Then you may put an end to their complaining against Me, so they will not die.”
17.11: So Moses did this. He did just as the Lord had told him.
17.12: Then the people of Israel said to Moses, “See, we are being destroyed! We are dying! We are all dying!
17.13: Everyone who comes near, who comes near the meeting tent of the Lord, must die. Are we all to be destroyed?”

18.1: The Lord said to Aaron, “You and your sons and those of your father’s house will carry the guilt for any sin done in the meeting tent. And you and your sons with you will carry the guilt of any sin of the religious leaders.
18.2: Bring with you your brothers also, the family of Levi, the family of your father. Then they may join you and help you while you and your sons are in front of the meeting tent of the Law.
18.3: They will help you and help in doing all the work of the tent. But they must not come near the objects of the meeting tent and the altar, or both they and you will die.
18.4: They will join you and help do all the work of the meeting tent. But no one else may come near you.
18.5: You must do the work of the meeting tent and the work of the altar, so there will no longer be anger on the people of Israel.
18.6: See, I Myself have taken your brothers the Levites from among the people of Israel. They are a gift to you, given to the Lord, to do the work for the meeting tent.
18.7: But you and your sons with you will do the religious work, in all that has to do with the altar and inside the curtain. I am giving you the work of being the religious leader as a gift. Anyone else who comes near the holy objects will be put to death.”
18.8: Then the Lord said to Aaron, “Now see, I am giving you all the gifts brought to Me that are not burned on the altar. I am giving them to you as a share, and to your sons as a share forever.
18.9: This will be yours from the most holy gifts, kept from the fire: every gift of theirs, even every grain gift, every sin gift and every guilt gift, which they bring to Me. They will be most holy for you and your sons.
18.10: You will eat it as the most holy gifts. Every male will eat it. It will be holy to you.
18.11: And this is yours: their gift that is lifted up and all the wave gifts of the people of Israel. I am giving them to you and to your sons and daughters with you, as a share forever. Everyone in your house who is clean may eat it.
18.12: I give to you all the best of the oil and all the best of the wine and of the grain, the first-fruits of what they give to the Lord.
18.13: The first-fruits ready to eat of all that is in their land, which they bring to the Lord, will be yours. Everyone in your house who is clean may eat it.
18.14: Everything in Israel that has been set apart to the Lord will be yours.
18.15: Every first-born of all flesh, man or animal, which they give to the Lord, will be yours. But you must pay the price and make free the first-born of man and the first-born of animals that are unclean.
18.16: You must make them free when they are one month old. The price to free them will be five large pieces of silver, the price decided upon at the meeting tent. One large piece of silver is worth twenty small pieces of silver.
18.17: But do not free the first-born of a bull or sheep or goat. For they are holy. You will put their blood on the altar and burn their fat as a gift by fire, a pleasing smell to the Lord.
18.18: But their meat will be yours, like the breast of a wave gift and like the right thigh are yours.
18.19: I have given to you and your sons and daughters, for a share forever, all the holy gifts which the people of Israel bring to the Lord. It is an agreement of salt forever before the Lord for you and your children with you.”
18.20: Then the Lord said to Aaron, “You will have no share in their land. You will not own any part of land among them. I am your part and your share among the people of Israel.
18.21: “See, I have given a tenth part of everything in Israel to the Levites, in return for the work they do, the work of the meeting tent.
18.22: The people of Israel must not come near the meeting tent again, or they will be guilty of sin and die.
18.23: Only the Levites may do the work around the meeting tent, and they will carry their sin. It will be a Law forever for all your children-to-come. And they will have no land among the people of Israel.
18.24: For I have given to the Levites one-tenth part of what the people of Israel give to the Lord. This is why I have said of them, ‘They will have no land among the people of Israel.’”
18.25: Then the Lord said to Moses,
18.26: “Say to the Levites, ‘When you take from the people of Israel the tenth which I have given you from them for your share, then give a gift from it to the Lord. Give one-tenth part of the tenth.
18.27: And your gift will be to you as if it were the grain from the grain-floor or all the wine from the crushed grapes.
18.28: So you must give a gift to the Lord from the tenth of what you receive from the people of Israel. And from it you must give the Lord’s gift to Aaron the religious leader.
18.29: Out of all the gifts to you, you must give every gift that should go to the Lord, from all the best of them. Give the holy part from them.’
18.30: “And say to them, ‘When you have given the best part of it, the rest of it will be to you as if it were the grain from the grain-floor and the wine from the crushed grapes.
18.31: You and those of your houses may eat it in any place. For it is your pay for your work in the meeting tent.
18.32: You will not be guilty because of it, when you have given the best of it. But do not make unclean the holy gifts of the people of Israel, or you will die.’”

19.1: Now the Lord said to Moses and Aaron,
19.2: “This is the Law which the Lord has told you. Tell the people of Israel to bring you a young red cow that is perfect, one that has never pulled a load.
19.3: You will give it to Eleazar the religious leader. It will be brought away from the tents and killed in front of him.
19.4: Next Eleazar the religious leader will take some of its blood with his finger, and put some of it toward the front of the meeting tent seven times.
19.5: Then Eleazar will watch the young cow being burned. Its skin, its flesh, its blood and its waste will be burned.
19.6: The religious leader will take cedar wood and hyssop and red cloth, and put it on the burning cow.
19.7: Then the religious leader will wash his clothes and wash his body in water. After this the religious leader may come among the tents, but he will be unclean until evening.
19.8: The one who burns it will also wash his clothes and wash his body in water. And he will be unclean until evening.
19.9: Now a man who is clean will gather up the ashes of the young cow and put them in a clean place away from the tents. They will be kept for the people of Israel to mix with the water used to make things clean, to take away sin.
19.10: The one who gathers the ashes of the young cow must wash his clothes. He will be unclean until evening. This will be a Law forever to the people of Israel and to the stranger who lives among them.
19.11: “The one who touches the dead body of any person will be unclean for seven days.
